DOC.HEAD: Michigan's Crockett First Congressman on Record for Decriminalization
With AM-Bennett-Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Rep. George Crockett has called for the decriminalization of drugs, becoming the first member of Congress to do so publicly and drawing sharp criticism from drug czar William Bennett. ``Decriminalization is the only solution,'' Crockett, D-Mich., said in an interview in Washington published Sunday in The Detroit News. ``Our courts are burdened down with these drug cases and there is nothing they can do about it,'' he said. ``And here we are talking about spending additional billions to build jails and prisons to send people to.'' Money now spent on drug enforcement should be shifted to job training for the urban poor, education, health care and day care, said Crockett, whose district includes Detroit's economically depressed east side. Crockett said he had no immediate plans to introduce legislation decriminalizing drugs because it could not win congressional approval. Told of Crockett's position, Bennett cursed, and said, ``Here we go. We were wondering who was going to be the first,'' the News said. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said he feared others in Congress could join Crockett and subvert the administration's anti-drug efforts. Last week, U.S. District Judge Robert Sweet became the first federal judge to publicly support decriminalization. Also favoring decriminalization are Baltimore Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke and economist Milton Friedman. Bennett said that giving drugs the same legal status as alcohol could cause even greater social and economic problems. ``Alcohol has done quite enough damage, thank you,'' he told the News. ``And if you want to see people using crack go from 1 (million) or 2 million to 10 million, make it as available as alcohol.'' Bennett also spoke against legalizing drugs Sunday in an appearance on the ABC-TV program ``This Week With David Brinkley.''
